properties.name: Brisighella, one day in 1954
properties.description: Posted by Lcarroli My father started a mechanic’s apprenticeship when he was very young. Unfortunately, the family couldn’t afford for him to stay on as an apprentice and had to stop when he was 17. Apparently, his older brother complained about working to support him while he was on the apprenticeship. The overwhelming picture of life in Italy during and after the war is of hardship. “I was ready to go anywhere to get a job,” he said. He tried to find work in the mines in Belgium, but was turned away. He also did a year’s military service as a paratrooper. One day in 1954 when my father, then aged 22, was in town at the weekly market, he was talking to a man who told him about his own work plans. He was telling my father he was going to start work in Sicily and said, “Why don’t you go ask about a job yourself.” “Oh,” I said. “So many people are waiting for years to go working there and they haven’t got a job yet.” So my father walked up to the ‘boss’ from Bologna, whose family was in the town and, so, sometimes came to the market. He asked, “I’d like a job with your company if it’s possible.” At first, he said they didn’t need anyone and then, when my father was leaving, he said, “You feel like working? Are you a good worker?” My father apparently said, “It’s not up to me to say whether I am good worker, but these are my hands.” My father showed him his hands and they were full of corns, callouses and blisters. Within a week my father in Cerignola, near Bari, ready to work on his first power line.

properties.name: Cerignola, 1954 to 1956
properties.description: Posted by Lcarroli Cerignola, 1954 to 1956 After securing a job and relocating to Cerignola, my father was nearly sacked because the company thought he had arrived late. It was a simple miscommunication that was easily made right. While based here he worked on lines from Bari to Foggia, from Naples to Salerno and also in the Alps. After some time working with SAE (the Italian parent company of EPT), my father said many people talked about working overseas – South Africa, America etc. He had lodged an application to go to South Africa, but was approached by the office to go to Australia. Having never heard of Australia, he had to look it up on a map. And he thought, “Why not? Let’s try that one.” “In Italy, we didn’t have much hope to do anything. I had in my mind, if I have a family, to have a family with a better life than what I had. And that’s what was in my mind all the time. If I get married and have no money to keep going, then that’s no life. That’s why I came to Australia. Plus, when you are young, you have adventure in front of you ...”

properties.name: Khancoban, 1965
properties.description: Posted by LcarroliThe photograph displayed here is an EPT Christmas card for 1965 showing the Murray 1 Power Station. This was part of the Snowy Mountain Hydro-Electric Scheme. The URL listed above links to a 1966 photograph in the National Archives of Australia showing transmission lines at Khancoban. This text links to a 1965 photograph of EPT linesmen at work held by the National Archives of Australia.

properties.name: Marayong, 1956
properties.description: Posted by LcarroliArrived in Sydney in 1956 by boat. The workers\' camp for newly arrived migrant workers was located in Marayong near Blacktown, Sydney. The camps were comprised of dormitory-style accommodation in large barracks.

properties.description: Posted by LcarroliPort Augusta to Whyalla, 1964, 132KV Construction of this line meant that the workers had to design and build a floating transmission tower. One of the photographs shows conditions in the camp. Those buildings could easily be accommodation for the workers.

properties.name: Yass
properties.description: Posted by LcarroliYass to Cabramurra, 1958 Yass to Dapto, late 1950s, Yass to Tumut, early to mid 1960s, 330KV My father worked on several lines around Yass over a ten year period. He says, "We went to Moss Vale [probably where the camp was located] and we did a power line from Yass to Wollongong – more or less – Dapto. And after, from there, we went up and did a line to the Snowy Mountains. That was from Yass to Cabramurra." This would have been in the late 1950s. According to his photographic record, my father was also working around Yass in the early to mid 1960s. The URL links to a series of 1958 photographs of transmission line construction held by the National Archives of Australia.
